body.p:
It was with deep re-
gret that I heard through our friend Rebecca that
you had been sick & that you were still feeble
although recovered. I ardently hope you may
be perfectly well ere this receit of this. I fear
you exert your physical strength that it may
keep pace with the vigor of your mental power
now that I must ask you not to do for the
activity of your mind tends to weaken a constitu
tion not naturally robust. If you would keep
your mind in repose I am satisfied your
health would improve I must beg you to be
more watchful of it & remember you belong
to your people who cannot afford that you
exercise your strength to its inquiry. You are too
important to our spiritual health for us to allow
you without a caution to neglect yourself.
My son begs to be kindly remembered I know not
whether my commendation or your own kind attentions
have impressed him so favorably but certain it is
that he awards you all the merit you do readily
deserve. S A has just come home from a long
visit to Johns island. She is much improved in health
& looks from the change; pure country air & the repose

which roaming in the woods & communing with nature in
her unsophisticated state is well calculated to improve
the health & the heart. The young people have had it quite
gay this winter there have been several private balls &
sociables & the arrival of strangers in the winter season
keeps those who desire society constantly in it. I have
been in such close mourning for the 2 past years
that I have been nowhere but where misfortune & ill health
preside. I however am determined if God protects us from any
ill I will for my Childrens sake visit & have company at home
& then I dare say catch a portion of their gaiety Even though
you were industrious in your efforts that my son should
captivate some of the fair assembly at the ? Malgré
toute cela he has returned unscathed not but that I
should be delighted for him to marry for there only is true
happiness to be enjoyed ? the marriage is of
two of congenial feelings & habits. The new minister
is expected in May I do not anticipate so beneficial a
change as many. I am of a strange turn when content
with present state of things I prefer no change even
though it may be a beneficial one I always fear to
require too much both from Creator & fellow
Mortals it is more a superstitious fear than an
amiable trait For I have found that to rest our
hopes too ? on any one desire often ends in
disappointment And the trials I have had to encounter
have checked all aspiring desires. I am on the ?
? to receive my daguerres I presume you know
Rebecca is going to send me her & her dear pets it is
so very kind of her to gratify me by such an attention.

What a delightful discovery is that of Daguerres
lot certainly should be much better than the
ancients for see the advantages we possess Daguerres
that give us the positive though inanimate presence
of those we love. Rail roads that swift as Eagles
wings bring them to us & most extraordinarily the Telegra
phic wires, which with a velocity incredible bring us in
formation (of those separated from us) of sorrow or hap-
piness! Yet man is no better his passions still
unchecked his propensities still leading him to evil
temptation lives with her smiles in spite of all the
advantages which this age of improvement & discovery
affords us. Mrs. Henry is better, Rumor with her poisoned
tongue has said that a change had come over here relig
ious feelings & that she did not find that consolation in her
own faith that she required. This I could not bring my
heart to believe & contradicted the report although it
came from authority hard to doubt. I could believe
that with the body in torture & the mind enfeebled
that she might be vacillating (because my friend wants
division of character) & beg the prayers of any good
man But as I had acted with her had seen how com
pletely she was satisfied with her own faith, I rejected
the idea and believed that as she regained her health
she would regain confidence in her own faith!
C'ol. Myers has written to beg that all reports
injurious to him should be refuted for there was
no truth in it. Mrs. Bryan is with her & it
is said that Mrs. Henry will never allow

to leave her again she is expected to visit Charleston
as soon as she is able to travel & then I will
give you a more correct statement — Remember
me kindly to my friends the Levys & all who
remember me. I am now writing without being
able to see, but I have had so many interruptions
that I am determined to finish in the dark
That you may soon be restored to health
is the sincere wish of your friend
